Award.AwardTitle: SBIR Phase II: Novel enzymes for producing homogeneous preparations of individual, monounsaturated industrial fatty acids
Award.AbstractNarration:
The broader impact/commercial potential of this Small Business Innovation Research (SBIR) Phase II project is the development and scale-up of a manufacturing platform for producing bio-based chemicals for application in lubricants. This manufacturing platform will utilize biologically derived sugar carbon-source and transform this carbon to higher value products via microbial fermentation. In contrast to the complex mixture of fatty acids currently produced in the oleochemical industry, the technology developed in this project will deliver a product stream containing simpler mixtures of monounsaturated fatty acids, which will eliminate the costly separation cost and be directly used to synthesize cost-efficient high-performance lubricants. Due to the improved lubrication performance of these molecules, this technology will potentially increase the energy efficiency of industrial and transportation machinery. By utilizing biological carbon feedstocks and producing bio-degradable products, this technology has the potential to reduce the environment footprint of the lubricant industry. More beneficial impacts are anticipated as we expand the application of monounsaturated fatty acids into other industries, such as surfactants and polymers. A large commercial potential of this technology has been identified in the lubricant market, currently valued at $123B per annum, and predicted to grow to $178B per annum in the next 5-years.

This SBIR Phase II project proposes to develop technology that will deliver novel bio-based monounsaturated fatty acids that provide new chemical structures allowing innovations in lubricants not possible from petroleum-based raw materials. Based on successful development of bacterial strains capable of producing enriched monounsaturated fatty acids in the Phase I project, the Phase II project will further de-risk the technology and scale up the capability to produce sufficient quantities of monounsaturated fatty acids to be evaluated by potential customers. By optimizing and scaling up the fermentation process and developing the product extraction procedure, large quantity of the first generation product (55% enriched monounsaturated fatty acids) will be produced. It will be used to chemically synthesize high-performance lubricants (i.e., polyol esters), whose physical-chemical and tribological properties will be evaluated and provided to potential customers. In this project, metabolic engineering, system biology, and evolutionary strategies will be applied to further improve the strains for producing second generation products that are more enriched in monounsaturated fatty acids (70-80%) and achieve commercial viable technology metrics. The monounsaturated fatty acids are envisioned as platform chemicals for subsequent chemical conversion to numerous specialty chemicals that have applications in additional markets, such as surfactants and polymers.

ProgramReference.Text: EXP PROG TO STIM COMP RES

POR.DRECONTENT:
VariFAS Biorenewables LLC is developing a microbial fermentation technology to produce novel fatty acids from agricultural sugars and offering them as new building blocks for the specialty chemical industry. Specifically, our novel fatty acids are medium chain omega-7 monounsaturated fatty acids and 3-hydroxyl fatty acids, which are not currently available in the market and not attainable from anywhere else. We are initially marketing them as new building blocks for synthesizing high performance biolubricants, biosurfactants, and cosmetics, because the new molecular structures can offer additional functional groups for derivatization and therefore improved product performance. In this SBIR Phase II project, the goal is to further de-risk our technology and scale up the capability to produce sufficient quantities (2-6 kilograms) of materials which can be evaluated by larger lubricant companies. This is to promoter collaboration with potential partners and permit entry into the lubricant market. The specific technical objectives of the Phase II projects are: (A) scaling up the technology to deliver first generation MUFA product, (B) Chemical synthesis of lubricants from MUFAs and performance evaluation, and (C) development of second-generation MUFA-producing microbial strains.

We have successfully completed all the tasks and delivered the proposed objectives. After fermentation optimization, the best fed-batch fermentation produced fatty acids at a titer of 45 g/L, yield of 0.21 g fatty acid/ g glucose (i.e. 60% of maximum theoretical yield), and productivity of 0.5 g/L/h. This product titer has been increased by 10 fold compared with the titer we had when we started the project (i.e. ~ 4 g/L). We have scaled up the fermentation process from 0.5 L to 14 L and to 130 L. With the downstream process developed, we recovered about eight kilogram fatty acid product in total from three batches 130-L fermentations. These fatty acids were used to synthesize prototype lubricants, including fatty acid 2-ehtylhexanol esters and TMP esters, of which the most important lubricant properties (including viscosity, viscosity index, pour point, cloud point, oxidation stability, and lubricity) have been tested. The results demonstrated that our prototype lubricants have great lubricity, viscosity index, and oxidative stability. Since the product recovered from the fermentation broth is a mixture of 4 different classes of fatty acids: MUFAs, 3-hydroxy saturated FAs, 3-hydroxyMUFAs and “normal” saturated-FAs, we developed a separation process to separate the mixture into four classes of FAs with very high purity. After separation, each class of FA may find even higher value applications. We’ve identified a lubricant company that is very interested in our 3-hydroxyl FAs, and sent them a few hundred grams of the sample materials for testing. To further improve the bacterial strain, we have tried different strategies, including modifying the thioesterase enzymes, modulating the gene expression level of thioesterases, co-overexpressing many other genes involved in FAS pathway, using alternative inducible promoters, and integrating the pathway genes into genome. We have obtained strain that produced fatty acid titer twice of our initial producing strain in the testing tubes. The fermentation optimization of this strain in fermenters is undergoing.

 


Last Modified: 01/10/2019
Modified by: Libuse Brachova
POR.POR_COPY_TXT: VariFAS Biorenewables LLC is developing a microbial fermentation technology to produce novel fatty acids from agricultural sugars and offering them as new building blocks for the specialty chemical industry. Specifically, our novel fatty acids are medium chain omega-7 monounsaturated fatty acids and 3-hydroxyl fatty acids, which are not currently available in the market and not attainable from anywhere else. We are initially marketing them as new building blocks for synthesizing high performance biolubricants, biosurfactants, and cosmetics, because the new molecular structures can offer additional functional groups for derivatization and therefore improved product performance. In this SBIR Phase II project, the goal is to further de-risk our technology and scale up the capability to produce sufficient quantities (2-6 kilograms) of materials which can be evaluated by larger lubricant companies. This is to promoter collaboration with potential partners and permit entry into the lubricant market. The specific technical objectives of the Phase II projects are: (A) scaling up the technology to deliver first generation MUFA product, (B) Chemical synthesis of lubricants from MUFAs and performance evaluation, and (C) development of second-generation MUFA-producing microbial strains. We have successfully completed all the tasks and delivered the proposed objectives. After fermentation optimization, the best fed-batch fermentation produced fatty acids at a titer of 45 g/L, yield of 0.21 g fatty acid/ g glucose (i.e. 60% of maximum theoretical yield), and productivity of 0.5 g/L/h. This product titer has been increased by 10 fold compared with the titer we had when we started the project (i.e. ~ 4 g/L). We have scaled up the fermentation process from 0.5 L to 14 L and to 130 L. With the downstream process developed, we recovered about eight kilogram fatty acid product in total from three batches 130-L fermentations. These fatty acids were used to synthesize prototype lubricants, including fatty acid 2-ehtylhexanol esters and TMP esters, of which the most important lubricant properties (including viscosity, viscosity index, pour point, cloud point, oxidation stability, and lubricity) have been tested. The results demonstrated that our prototype lubricants have great lubricity, viscosity index, and oxidative stability. Since the product recovered from the fermentation broth is a mixture of 4 different classes of fatty acids: MUFAs, 3-hydroxy saturated FAs, 3-hydroxyMUFAs and "normal" saturated-FAs, we developed a separation process to separate the mixture into four classes of FAs with very high purity. After separation, each class of FA may find even higher value applications. We?ve identified a lubricant company that is very interested in our 3-hydroxyl FAs, and sent them a few hundred grams of the sample materials for testing. To further improve the bacterial strain, we have tried different strategies, including modifying the thioesterase enzymes, modulating the gene expression level of thioesterases, co-overexpressing many other genes involved in FAS pathway, using alternative inducible promoters, and integrating the pathway genes into genome. We have obtained strain that produced fatty acid titer twice of our initial producing strain in the testing tubes. The fermentation optimization of this strain in fermenters is undergoing.
